newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia 96 gold output seen lower -union leaders.
newsitem.headline: Russia 96 gold output seen lower -union leaders.

text.p: Russia will produce some 100-105 tonnes of gold this year compared with 122 tonnes in 1995, leaders of the country's gold miners said on Wednesday.
"This is far below the 1989 level, when Russia's gold output peaked at some 160 tonnes," Valery Braiko, Chairman of the Gold Industry Workers' Union, told a news conference.

Viktor Tarakanovsky, Chairman of the Union of Russian Gold Mining Collectives, which unites some 35,000 prospecters and accounts for about 60 percent of gold output, said last year Russia accounted for around four percent of world gold production, but its share "will be even smaller in 1996."
Braiko said that as of August 21 this year Russian gold plants received 60 tonnes of gold for processing, compared to 73 tonnes in the same period of 1995.
Braiko said the absence of a viable precious metals market and a metal exchange in Russia was one of the main reasons for the deplorable state of the gold industry.

"In Russia, there exists only one buyer of gold -- the state. But it cannot fulfill its obligations," he said adding that the government still owed gold producers more than one trillion roubles ($186 million) for earlier gold purchases.
Braiko said high interest rates available to banks from other operations meant that serious investment in the recession-battered industry could not be expected.

"Such a situation creates fertile soil for growing criminality ...Up to five percent of all Russian gold leaks onto black markets, where gold producers get cash at once and pay no taxes," Braiko said.
